text:
Just a hypothesis - maybe you need some social blanket, even if there's no financial blanket, to found a startup, considering all the risks it brings along? And usually the social privileges of caste / gender allow you to do that?

If you're from a marginalized community, and you're starting a business, you'd focus on profits and not growth, which most startups don't :man-shrugging: 

Finally, early stage employees only onboard by building strong relationships with the founders, and folks tend to gravitate to people that belong to the same social strata as them.

And this has a snowball effect - the initial set of employees pave the way for the next, and then the next. And so on. it's a viscious cycle.

Oh, and one more thing - a 70% meritorious candidate from a marginalized community will add more value to your org than a 90% meritorious candidate who has been raised by and exposed to the same culture / way of thinking as you. The whole point of diversity and inclusion is to bring different perspectives together, and make them work in tandem.

Hey folks, need some help.

I am currently planning to take a short sabbatical from work after spending around 8 years in the workforce. Currently in one of the larger B2B SaaS companies in India and getting paid decently well. However, I'm facing burnout and lack of enthusiasm at work for a while, so want to chill out for a month and get my mojo back before diving into the next stage of my career. I have 2 questions

1. How difficult do you think it will be to find an equivalent role given this break?
2. Should I expect a drop in my negotiating power since I won't have the luxury of staying at my current role?

text:
The one thing I love about this group is how we are accepting of all functions tech, non tech Ops etc. I recently DMed someone who works in the Strategy and Ops space launching a community for people iin that space working in those type of roles asking if I could join the group despite being a marketer just so I learn and expand my knowledge but was disappointed to learn its exclusive for strategy and Chief of staff roles.

While understand why this might be the case, it seems slightly close minded to me that you deny someone the opportunity to learn even if its not someone from the same field. Now he did mention they would let me in if they ever open it up for mentoring but it just left a slightly sour taste in my mouth. Maybe I'm looking at this wrong but I feel it would be harmless if someone was genuinely interested in a field and just wanted to learn from people who've been there done that.

text:
I work in the insurtech space. Not in the marketing / growth team, but as an arbitrary extension of it. We're a fairly new company, atleast compared to the competition. The way folks in my marketing team think about growth / their work / new ideas or the lack thereof is absolutely horrendous. In my previous gigs, have worked with absolutely solid folks who keep pushing boundaries and looking at these guys makes me sad.

I see them posting videos of them dancing and sharing pet videos on our LI, while the competition is doing some seriously engaging stuff around insurance. I've tried giving these guys a sense of where we're losing out but they're happy in their own mirage. I'm done poking my nose where it doesn't belong now.

text:
I have been approached by my company's direct competitor. Both are US based companies. Can someone help me in driving this decision? Context: 

Current company
Pay is less (around 26 LPA). Not sure about a promotion. Good leadership. Amazing work life balance. Vested around 1.5 years worth of esops and they are at 3x value right now. Hoping for a unicorn in the next round which will happen any time now.

Competitor
Scope hai to negotiate a good hike since they're poaching and in $$ (>>50LPA) hehe. Not sure about culture or leadership. Not sure about esops but it's already a Unicorn so jump in $$ value zyaada nahi hai. 

- I want to continue in my current company but the pay is definitely tempting.
- I'm skeptical about the competitor reaching out for strategic information in the name of "assignments".
- Should I go ahead with all the rounds and then go back to my company and ask for a bigger hike? My CEO gets super anxious about this company lol. This competitor hired 30 Google devs and my CEO was all over the place about the massive spend on talent. I can play to his ego but it can as easily backfire if he gets offended. 
- There's no clause as such in my offer letter, around joining competitors.  

Any help here would be great

text: I have been talking to a lot of marketers who are working with remote companies and are getting paid ~60LPA even though they work out of India while the rest of the company is spread across the world. They are not even that experienced and are in non-leadership roles. I have been working with Indian SaaS startups for ~5 years now, get ~20LPA but it hurts to see people with my level of experience go out and get paid so high. I'm thinking of switching but curious to understand if the overall Indian SaaS ecosystem is doing anything to match the global standards? (And just for argument's sake, assume I have more than enough skill and experience needed to be qualified for my role anywhere in the world)

text:
[Need Advice]

I'm the "boss" but we're a small team and we have REALLY strong bonds.

One employee wasn't doing very well and it it continued, she may have had to be put in a PIP. So I coached her and provided the training she needed. We even set clear expectations on what she needed to achieve. She also started putting in efforts from her end.

The problem is, at the same time, due to some personal reasons, her manager stopped performing as well. It was my fault that I didn't notice this till 2 weeks later.

So she hasn't delivered on the expectations we had set earlier. I'm not sure if she would have if given a fair shot or not.

The easiest solution now would be to fix the management problem and just give her another 2-4 weeks IMO.

The problem is that her performance review is coming up that will also decide her hike.

How would you suggest I handle this? I want to be fair, but not send the wrong signal by rewarding bad performance.

text: NEED ADVICE GUYS!! I have been working for almost 10 years now and feel I haven't been able to unlock my true potential. I come from a Tier-1 arts college but somehow it has been always tough get likeable roles at top companies (strategy,ops and business roles). There have been a lot of CBC in the market in the areas of SaaS marketing, performance marketing and micro MBAs (Stoa) but I'm skeptical if they will be able to unlock the true value. I already have 720 in GMAT and I'm tempted to apply to the ISB and IIMs. Should I go ahead and get that validation and be a part of the peer group I always wanted to be? Or should I save 40 lacs and keep navigating through identity-crisis and rely on these CBC to upskill?

Sometimes when I have an existential crisis about being in marketing, I thank God I ended up in B2B. More jargon everywhere than hair on my head, but atleast we're a bit more honest about the fact that we mostly care about profits and selling. Just a little bit.

The aspirational fluff in B2C/ D2C is on another level. EdTech, Fast fashion etc are some of the worst offenders. Lot of stomach churning stuff that happens, unfortunately someone left the marketing on full blast.

Guess my virtue-signalling has gone on enough. Rant over, jai B2B.

text:
> How can we stop proving our credibility for all the backend work that we pull as marketers that our 'Heads' or so-called 'Leads' take credits for in the name of 'proud of mah team'

In my company, other teams jump in at the time of project completion to 'review' your work, and then go to the thousands of 'Heads' we have in our org with the completed version or post it on Slack threads with the CEO for clout.

I don't think you can run from it. This is is my fifth company and the politics is strikingly similar to my previous companies. Everywhere there is a set of bad apples that do this s#!t and rise in the ranks quickly. And most often, these are your 'failed entrepreneurs' or 'B-school graduates' who think their only skill is project management but they suck at that the most.

My advice: keep your head down, learn as much as you can, join an early stage startup and create the right culture from scratch.

text: I see lot of passionate threads on salary/packages/increments. I see that most of us are getting better at negotiating and asking for what we are worth but not adding the component of cost/standard of living, peace of mind/pursuit of happiness and some other abstract/philosophical concepts. I have learnt a lot from my dad and mom and my own way of being secure financially in startups in this regard as they lead happy and healthy post retirement lives. So if people are interested I can document my lessons. I will not spend a lot of time documenting it if I don’t see interest as I respect how most people in my circle don’t welcome this thought - that salary packages can be calculated incorporating factors well beyond past CTC/future increment and stage of business

Hope more companies give feedback and help you grow after the interview process when you don't get selected. I have given interviews for digital marketing role for around 5-10 companies and the experience has been more or less same and sometimes underwhelming.

A couple of companies that stood out were Wingman and Springworks. The person who interviewed me at Wingman sent across material on request and was responsive via LI and email helping me with most of my doubts. Sprigworks the entire process was seamless and helpful. We need more companies like this that leave a good taste even if you aren't getting selected. I personally wish both these companies reach great heights such was the experience.

Hi all! Would be great if I could have your experienced advice:

I have been working in Sales for the past 8 years, and want to transition to PMM (or Strategy) Role. The reason: Past 3 companies I have worked with were start-up's, and the close collaboration b/w Sales & Marketing made me realise my knack for overall GTM planning (I don't like sales anymore...help me please!!). The problem: I have zero clue on where to and how to begin with this. I have 3 questions:
1. Where do I begin? (Currently on LinkedIn Learning courses on PMM, but if there's something else, I'd be thankful for your suggestions)

3. In the current space, any suggestions on the orgs I should keep an eye out for, for any opps? (out of curiosity)
Thanks in advance

PS: I am comfortable with responses in any language... desperate for guidance, and I will use Google Translate if needed :D

text:
Can we please stop sharing value in this community!

1. I have experience outside this community that is AWESOME and this community doesn’t count in front of that!
2. Why should I be grateful for people here who are filling their survey to help each other. (there are some errors in the data!) It was conducted by Gallop, and not an open community trying their best to educate and help each other.
3. And there is no visibility on who is filling the survey so that I can shit post and get insecure when I see someone with lesser experience getting paid more than me

It’s a good attempt but the outcome is just poor and misleading me to make more errors and continue setting the salary bar and expectations really low in our market.

text:
Appraisal seasons grief | Need help 

In the last year, I've had 3 managers. 

First left in April. She was the Head of Marketing, and within 6 months, they were discussing moving me to the US office, that's how impressed they were with the work. Then a new leader above her came in and completely changed the org structure. She obviously left.

My next manager left in October. I was working closely with him for almost 7 months. 

Then I started reporting to the CMO directly. He sits out of the US office, and is now leaving 2 weeks before the India appraisal cycle ends. I was looking for an exceptional hike (meeting industry benchmarks) and was leaning on him to put up a good case. Anything above 30%, requires CXO approval. 

The role is transitioning to a new decision maker who joined in Feb. I have talked to her all but 4 times till now. 

I have written 13 pages /3000 words documenting my work and impact, but it can NEVER be similar to as truly, closely working with someone who'll also vouch for you because they've seen value. 

I really need some mentoring and handholding to work around this and avoid feeling exploited like in the last cycle. Please drop a comment if you can help and I'll DM you.

text: I absolutely LOATHE how product marketing teams just swoop in and snatch away messaging & positioning from the content team. I work at a company that didn't have the product marketing function and I handled that aspect (rather well) all by myself and now my team gets random ass briefs from the new product marketing team and our input is not taken into consideration at all. Feels like I've become an assistant to the product marketing team, there's no clear demarcation between our work and theirs and too many cooks are definitely spoiling the broth.

text:
Few pointers:

• Data points are limited so don't look too deep into specific numbers. Look at it directionally.
• Companies come in all shapes and sizes. Hence, the "leadership" can mean different things depending on the size, growth rate, leader experience, funding raised etc. This data has not been normalized for all those factors.
• In many companies, a reportee CAN and does make more than the manager. Just being a manager does not make you more valuable than your reportees (just like in Cricket, the captain may or may not be the best player. Captaincy requires different skills. You'll find this true in many high-performing engineering teams where the rockstar engineer would hate to carry on managerial work as they would rather solve interesting/challening technical problems than deal with imperfect humans). In marketing, this is especially true with somewhat technical skills (ops, performance, brand), which are otherwise rare to find. Not to mention some sales reps may also make more than their managers.
